ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Social Anxiety and/or Selective Mutism. Select the appropriate response: The participant and/or the parent endorsed criteria and/or symptoms for this section of the K-SADS-PL (Social Anxiety Disorder and/or Selective Mutism).
Fear of Social Situations. Are you a very shy person?
Fear of Social Situations. Have you ever felt nervous, self-conscious or shy around people that you didn't know very well?
Fear of Social Situations. Is it difficult for you to be with other kids - even kids you know?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Speaking in front of others (e.g. answering questions in class, giving oral reports, show & tell)?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Eating in front of others (e.g. school cafeteria, fast food restaurant)?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Writing in front of others (e.g. at chalkboard, taking tests)?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Using public bathrooms when others are around?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Performance situations (e.g. gym class, recess, sports activities)?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Changing clothes when others are present (e.g. in gym/pool locker room)?
Fear of Social Situations. What kind of situations make you feel uncomfortable? -- Going to parties or social events?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: Has there ever been a time when you were shy, nervous, or uncomfortable in social situations?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: Has there ever been a time when you were uncomfortable doing things in front of other people?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: Has there ever been a time when you avoided social situations?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: Has there ever been a time when you avoided social situations? Why was that?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: Did you feel embarrassed in some way or afraid that you would be watched or judged by your peers?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: How old where you when you first started to feel this way?
Fear of Social Situations. MORE QUESTIONS IF NEEDED: For how long have you been feeling this way?
Fear of Social Situations. Current: Summary Rating.
Notes: 0 = No information; 1 = Not present; 2 = Subthreshold: Clearly self-conscious and uncomfortable in social performance situations; avoids only 1 or 2 activities that are not critical to the childs well being (e.g. avoiding large parties where child knows no one); 3 = Threshold: Considerable self-consciousness that makes the child uncomfortable in several social settings; at least 1 activity is avoided (e.g. repeatedly and persistently refusing to answer questions in class, avoiding gathering where child does not know everyone). A marked and persistent fear of social performance situations - fears acting in a way (or showing anxiety symptoms) that will be humiliating or embarrassing. DO NOT CODE AS THRESHOLD IF THE CHILDS ONLY FEAR IS GIVING ORAL PRESENTATIONS AT SCHOOL; 4= Yes; 5= No

ElementDescription: Fear of Social Situations. Past: Summary Rating.
Notes: 0 = No information; 1 = Not present; 2 = Subthreshold: Clearly self-conscious and uncomfortable in social performance situations; avoids only 1 or 2 activities that are not critical to the childs well being (e.g. avoiding large parties where child knows no one); 3 = Threshold: Considerable self-consciousness that makes the child uncomfortable in several social settings; at least 1 activity is avoided (e.g. repeatedly and persistently refusing to answer questions in class, avoiding gathering where child does not know everyone). A marked and persistent fear of social performance situations - fears acting in a way (or showing anxiety symptoms) that will be humiliating or embarrassing. DO NOT CODE AS THRESHOLD IF THE CHILDS ONLY FEAR IS GIVING ORAL PRESENTATIONS AT SCHOOL; 4= Yes; 5= No

Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Have you ever felt like you couldn't talk in school or other situations?
Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Have you ever felt so shy that you just couldn't say anything?
Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Have you ever felt so shy that you just couldn't say anything? Even to another kid?
Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Are there certain situations that you just can't talk
Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Current: Summary Rating.
Notes: 0 = No information; 1 = Not present; 2 = Subthreshold: Child unable to speak in novel situations, including the start of school year, but symptom does not persist; 3 = Threshold: Consistent failure to speak in social situations when expected to speak; 4= Yes; 5= No

ElementDescription: Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Past: Summary Rating.
Notes: 0 = No information; 1 = Not present; 2 = Subthreshold: Child unable to speak in novel situations, including the start of school year, but symptom does not persist; 3 = Threshold: Consistent failure to speak in social situations when expected to speak; 4= Yes; 5= No

ElementDescription: Failure to Speak in Specific Social Situations. Interviewer Notes.

Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Performance situations.
Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Eating in front of others.
Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Using public restrooms.

Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Changing in front of others.

Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Talking in any social situations.
Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Other.
Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Review Situations that Elicit Distress. Record 'yes' if either parent or child identify the situation as distressing. Other situations: specify.

Supplement: Social Anxiety Disorder/Selective Mutism. Marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Current: Summary Rating

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder A. Marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Examples include social interactions (e.g., having a conversation, meeting unfamiliar people), being observed (e.g., eating or drinking), and performing in front of others (e.g., giving a speech). NOTE: In children, the anxiety must occur in peer settings and not just in interactions with adults. Does the participant meet Criterion A - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder A. Marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Examples include social interactions (e.g., having a conversation, meeting unfamiliar people), being observed (e.g., eating or drinking), and performing in front of others (e.g., giving a speech). NOTE: In children, the anxiety must occur in peer settings and not just in interactions with adults. Does the participant meet Criterion A - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder B. The individual fears that he or she will act in a way or show anxiety symptoms that will be negatively evaluated (i.e., will be humiliating or embarrassing; will lead to rejection or offend others)  Does the participant meet Criterion B - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder B. The individual fears that he or she will act in a way or show anxiety symptoms that will be negatively evaluated (i.e., will be humiliating or embarrassing; will lead to rejection or offend others)  Does the participant meet Criterion B - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder C. The social situations almost always provoke fear or anxiety. Note: In children, the fear or anxiety may be expressed by crying, tantrums, freezing, clinging, shrinking, or failing to speak in social situations. Does the participant meet Criterion C - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder C. The social situations almost always provoke fear or anxiety. Note: In children, the fear or anxiety may be expressed by crying, tantrums, freezing, clinging, shrinking, or failing to speak in social situations. Does the participant meet Criterion C - MSP?
DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder D. The social situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety. Does the participant meet Criterion D - CE?
DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder D. The social situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety. Does the participant meet Criterion D - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder E. The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual threat posed by the social situation and to the sociocultural context. Does the participant meet Criterion E - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder E. The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual threat posed by the social situation and to the sociocultural context. Does the participant meet Criterion E - MSP?
DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder F. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more. Does the participant meet Criterion F - CE?
DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder F. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more. Does the participant meet Criterion F - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder G. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. Does the participant meet Criterion G - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder G. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. Does the participant meet Criterion G - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder H. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition. Does the participant meet Criterion H - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder H. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition. Does the participant meet Criterion H - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder I. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder, such as panic disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, or autism spectrum disorder. Does the participant meet Criterion I - CE?
Notes: 0 = Explained by another mental disorder; 1 = Not explained by another mental disorder

ElementDescription: DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder I. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder, such as panic disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, or autism spectrum disorder. Does the participant meet Criterion I - MSP?
Notes: 0 = Explained by another mental disorder; 1 = Not explained by another mental disorder

ElementDescription: DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder J. If another medical condition (e.g., Parkinson's disease, obesity, disfigurement from burns or injury) is present, the fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly unrelated or is excessive. Does the participant meet Criterion J - CE?
Notes: 0 = Fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly related or not excessive; 1 = Fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly unrelated or excessive

ElementDescription: DSM 5 Criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder J. If another medical condition (e.g., Parkinson's disease, obesity, disfigurement from burns or injury) is present, the fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly unrelated or is excessive. Does the participant meet Criterion J - MSP?
Notes: 0 = Fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly related or not excessive; 1 = Fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly unrelated or excessive

ElementDescription: Specifier. Specify if Performance ONLY: if the fear is restricted to speaking or performing in public.
Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Summary CE: # of criteria met.
Notes: If participant meets all criteria, value will be 10.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Considering all clinical information available, does this participant meet criteria for the CE?
Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Summary CE - Final.
Notes: Calculation: if (([sa10sce1_v2_v3] = 10 and [sa10sce2_v2_v3] = 2) or ([sa10sce1_v2_v3] < 10 and [sa10sce2_v2_v3] = 2), 2, if (([sa10sce1_v2_v3] = 10 and [sa10sce2_v2_v3] = 1) or ([sa10sce1_v2_v3] < 10 and [sa10sce2_v2_v3] = 1), 1, if ([sa10sce2_v2_v3]=0, 0, "NaN"))). If value=2, social anxiety disorder diagnosis met.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Summary MSP: # of criteria met.
Notes: If participant meets all criteria, value will be 10.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Considering all clinical information available, does this participant meet criteria for the MSP?
Evidence of Social Anxiety Disorder. Summary MSP - Final.
Notes: Calculation: if (([sa10smsp1_v2_v3] = 10 and [sa10smsp2_v2_v3] = 2) or ([sa10smsp1_v2_v3] < 10 and [sa10smsp2_v2_v3] = 2), 2, if (([sa10smsp1_v2_v3] = 10 and [sa10smsp2_v2_v3] = 1) or ([sa10smsp1_v2_v3] < 10 and [sa10smsp2_v2_v3] = 1), 1, if ([sa10smsp2_v2_v3]=0, 0, "NaN"))). If value=2, social anxiety disorder diagnosis met.

ElementDescription: DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism A. Consistent failure to speak in specific social situations in which there is an expectation for speaking (e.g., at school) despite speaking in other situations. Does the participant meet Criterion A - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism A. Consistent failure to speak in specific social situations in which there is an expectation for speaking (e.g., at school) despite speaking in other situations. Does the participant meet Criterion A - MSP?
DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism B. The disturbance interferes with educational or occupational achievement or with social communication. Does the participant meet Criterion B - CE?
DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism B. The disturbance interferes with educational or occupational achievement or with social communication. Does the participant meet Criterion B - MSP?
DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism C. The duration of the disturbance is at least 1 month (not limited to the first month of school). Does the participant meet Criterion C - CE?
DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism C. The duration of the disturbance is at least 1 month (not limited to the first month of school). Does the participant meet Criterion C - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism D. The failure to speak is not attributable to a lack of knowledge of, or comfort with, the spoken language required in the social situation. Does the participant meet Criterion D - CE?

DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism D. The failure to speak is not attributable to a lack of knowledge of, or comfort with, the spoken language required in the social situation. Does the participant meet Criterion D - MSP?

DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism E. The disturbance is not better explained by a communication disorder (e.g., childhood-onset fluency disorder) and does not occur exclusively during the course of autism spectrum disorder, schizophrenia, or another psychotic disorder. Does the participant meet Criterion E - CE?
Notes: 0 = Better explained and occur exclusively; 1 = Not better explained and does not occur exclusively

ElementDescription: DSM 5 Criteria for Selective Mutism E. The disturbance is not better explained by a communication disorder (e.g., childhood-onset fluency disorder) and does not occur exclusively during the course of autism spectrum disorder, schizophrenia, or another psychotic disorder. Does the participant meet Criterion E - MSP?
Notes: 0 = Better explained and occur exclusively; 1 = Not better explained and does not occur exclusively

ElementDescription: Evidence of Selective Mutism. Summary CE: # of criteria met.
Notes: If participant meets all criteria, value will be 5.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Selective Mutism. Considering all clinical information available, does this participant meet criteria for the CE?
Evidence of Selective Mutism. Summary CE - Final.
Notes: Calculation: if (([smd10sce1_v2_v3] = 5 and [smd10sce2_v2_v3] = 2) or ([smd10sce1_v2_v3] < 5 and [smd10sce2_v2_v3] = 2), 2, if (([smd10sce1_v2_v3] = 5 and [smd10sce2_v2_v3] = 1) or ([smd10sce1_v2_v3] < 5 and [smd10sce2_v2_v3] = 1), 1, if ([smd10sce2_v2_v3]=0, 0, "NaN"))). If value=2, selective mutism diagnosis met.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Selective Mutism. Summary MSP: # of criteria met.
Notes: If participant meets all criteria, value will be 5.

ElementDescription: Evidence of Selective Mutism. Considering all clinical information available, does this participant meet criteria for the MSP?
Evidence of Selective Mutism. Summary MSP - Final.
Notes: Calculation: if (([smd10smsp1_v2_v3] = 5 and [smd10smsp2_v2_v3] = 2) or ([smd10smsp1_v2_v3] < 5 and [smd10smsp2_v2_v3] = 2), 2, if (([smd10smsp1_v2_v3] = 5 and [smd10smsp2_v2_v3] = 1) or ([smd10smsp1_v2_v3] < 5 and [smd10smsp2_v2_v3] = 1), 1, if ([smd10smsp2_v2_v3]=0, 0, "NaN"))). If value=2, selective mutism diagnosis met.
